Speaker: hoppin' bob
Dialogue: Okay, ladies, got some fresh meat for ya!

Speaker: hoppin' bob
Dialogue: We ain't got no wallflowers at Camp 8. Everybody gotta dance eventually. But don't worry, they won't try nothing tonight. That would take all of the fun outta the courtship.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: Got three miles of ditch to clear today. Let's keep it moving!

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: I don't believe this before Abe jive. I didn't go to night school to sing in no Mississippi Boys Choir!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I wouldn't do that if I was you.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Shut up. It's too damn hot. What do you know, anyway?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Told ya.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: Why ain't his pick swinging?

Speaker: hoppin' bob
Dialogue: Why ain't that pick swinging?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: It's too hot, boss. I'm tired.

Speaker: hoppin' bob
Dialogue: He says it's too hot, boss.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: Too hot, huh? Well, you tell that lazy jiggaboo the state of Mississippi ain't interested in his meteorological assessments.

Speaker: hoppin' bob
Dialogue: Listen up, jiggaboo! State of Mississippi ain't interested in your... in your...  metropolitan assets!

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: Tell him the state of Mississippi is only interested in getting this ditch cleared by sundown.

Speaker: hoppin' bob
Dialogue: State of Mississippi wants this ditch cleared by sundown. You got that?!

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: I got it... boss.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: He don't sound like he's from 'round here.

Speaker: hoppin' bob
Dialogue: He's from New York City. That one, too.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: New York. That's up north, ain't it? They'll find we do things different down here.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: We noticed.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: Looks like we got a couple of live ones. How long these boys in for?

Speaker: hoppin' bob
Dialogue: Judge gave 'em the long ride.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: Life, huh? They step outta line again, we'll shorten up that sentence real fast.

Speaker: biscuit
Dialogue: Drink it up!

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: Either of you new fellas know how to read? I've had this letter four months now.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: You can't read? None of these guys can read?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Last fella who could read made parole 'round Christmas.

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: I don't even know who this is from.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Here, gimme that.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: It's from your mama's neighbor, Mrs. Tidwell. She thought you oughta know that your second cousin Bo died.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: And your other cousin, Sally, on your daddy's side, she died.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Apparently, your sister died.

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: Jenny?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: No, it says Marleen here.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Oh, wait, looks like Jenny died, too.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Then it goes on for a while about how the crop didn't come in on accounta the frost.  She finishes up with something about a tornado and how your mama and your daddy died in that. But don't worry none. She'll take care of the dog. That is, if it gets over the worms.

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: Appreciate it.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Anybody else need anything read?

Speaker: jangle leg
Dialogue: How you doin'?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: I'm all right.

Speaker: jangle leg
Dialogue: You ever done time before?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: You kidding? I've been in and out of prison my entire life. Mostly in. I'm hard-core.

Speaker: jangle leg
Dialogue: Then you won't have no problem making the adjustment. You need anything, help of any kind, gimme a holler. Name's Jangle Leg.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: 'Preciate it. Claude.

Speaker: jangle leg
Dialogue: Soft and supple. Like a lady's.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: I try to moisturize regularly.

Speaker: hoppin' bob
Dialogue: Hey, Jangle Leg, what'd I tell you about pitching woo on the job?

Speaker: jangle leg
Dialogue: Sorry, Cap'n.

Speaker: hoppin' bob
Dialogue: Break's over! Back to work!

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Why do you think they call him Jangle Leg?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Somebody just told me he wins the three-legged race every year.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: So?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: He does it all by himself.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What is that?

Speaker: cookie
Dialogue: Creamed chip beef on toast. Except we're outta beef, so I had to improvise.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Can't I get one of those steaks you got grilling back there?

Speaker: cookie
Dialogue: Those are for trusties, unless you got thirty cents or two packs of cigs.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Excuse me, I don't like it when the food touches each other, so if you could just --  -- keep everything separate.

Speaker: biscuit
Dialogue: Eyes front, mister!

Speaker: cookie
Dialogue: Problem with the toast?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: It's fine now.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Stop aggravating people. Just eat your food.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: This fork is filthy.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: The fork is the least of your worries, Claude.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What's your name?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Me? Willie Long.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What are you in for, Willie?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: That's a long story...

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: When he was 13 years old he killed a son-of-a-bitch with a claw hammer.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: They never proved that.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: What a second, you've been in here since you were thirteen?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What about you, Radio?

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: Armed robbery.

Speaker: jangle leg
Dialogue: Damn liar. Bitch killed his sister with an axe.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: She was my half-sister. Shit, I ain't the son-of-a-bitch who poisoned my own parents.

Speaker: biscuit
Dialogue: They deserved it. Very strict.

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: What about you, Biscuit? You nearly skinned your poor old landlady alive.

Speaker: cookie
Dialogue: At least he didn't kill Santa Claus with his bare hands.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You killed Santa Claus?

Speaker: biscuit
Dialogue: On Christmas Eve.

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: He wasn't the Santa Claus, he was just wearing the suit and ringing a bell.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What did you guys do?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I kinda lost track of how many people we killed that night. Must have been 15 or twenty -- not counting women and children. It was a real bloodbath. All that screaming...

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Pack of lies. Don't listen to him. We didn't kill nobody. We were railroaded. And we gonna prove that.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: He just blocked it out. Nigger's crazy. He's the one who did all the stabbing. He's capable of some heinous shit.  How 'bout him down there?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Goldmouth? They say he was born out back behind the shithouse. That's what they say.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You all been here a long time. Doesn't anybody ever escape from this place?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: They run but they never get too far.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: Couple years back, Cookie made it clear to Greenville.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Greenville, that the nearest town?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: It's a two-day walk if you don't get lost. Take a mighty cagey country boy to navigate the woods and bayous between here and there.

Speaker: biscuit
Dialogue: Those dogs they got can sniff a skid mark in your underpants from a half- mile off.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Alright, well, let's say you make it to Greenville. What's there, anyway?

Speaker: cookie
Dialogue: Grandma Dodi's Pork Rib Joint.

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: That's where they nabbed him.

Speaker: cookie
Dialogue: Didn't even get to have my peach cobbler.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: The most important thing they got in Greenville is a train that heads up north.

Speaker: goldmouth
Dialogue: Hey, girl, you gonna eat your corn bread?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: No, man. I want you to have it.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Wait up there, Claude. You give that guy your corn bread and the next thing you know you'll be ironing his shirts and clipping his toenails.

Speaker: goldmouth
Dialogue: Maybe I oughta eat your corn bread.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: My corn bread? Oh no, my friend. I love corn bread.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I thought my mama made good corn bread but this is really something special.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Who knew I'd have to come all the way down to this here prison, deep in the asshole of the great state of Mississippi, to find such a tasty piece of corn bread?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: And who knew that in this great corn bread-making institution I'd come face to face with the biggest, ugliest, stinkiest, ugliest gold- mouthed negro in the entire world. Now get out of my face before I lose my appetite!

Speaker: goldmouth
Dialogue: How you like your corn bread now, New York?

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: Come on, New York, you can do better than that! Get up and show him how they do it in Harlem!

Speaker: cookie
Dialogue: I appreciate you going to all this trouble over my corn bread. I don't get a lot of compliments in my line of work.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Your pal's getting the tar whipped out of him on your account.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: How many times I got to tell you? He ain't my pal. Besides, he looks like he knows what he's doing.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Alright, alright...

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Hey, Ray, I think you made your point, whatever that is. Maybe now's a good time to throw in the towel. You know what I'm saying?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Shit, Goldmouth. Back in New York, I know bitches who hit harder than you.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: The man's taken enough of a beating. Let's get him inside.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Got him good, huh, Claude? He won't be bothering us anytime soon.

Speaker: biscuit
Dialogue: Shame, shame, that's your name.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Request permission to go to the tonk, boss.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: I don't see no wedding ring, Banks. Conjugal visits are for married prisoners only.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: You think you could make an exception just this once, boss? She came all the way down from New York.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: I don't need the Baptists on my back, but I suppose I could issue a temporary marriage license for a nominal fee.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: I now pronounce you man and wife.  Claude Banks going to the tonk!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Biscuit, when you're done with Jangle Leg, you think you could squeeze me in?

Speaker: biscuit
Dialogue: Thought you'd never ask. Biscuit needs some gravy.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I'm talking about a haircut.

Speaker: biscuit
Dialogue: Cost you a pair of nylons.

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: Hey, Ray, Goldmouth don't believe me. Ain't it so they got trains up in New York City that run under the streets?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: They're called subways. A nickel will take you from one end of Manhattan to the other. Helluva ride, too.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: Hey, Ray, you ever been to the Cotton Club?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Sure I've been to the Cotton Club. It's pretty sweet. But it don't hold a candle to the Boom Boom Room. That's where the real action is.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: What's the Boom Boom Room?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: That's my joint. The swinginest nightclub in town.

Speaker: cookie
Dialogue: You got your own nightclub?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Well, not yet. It's still in the planning stages.

Speaker: goldmouth
Dialogue: So it don't exist.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Just because it's in my mind, Goldmouth, don't mean it ain't real. Everything worth anything starts with a dream.

Speaker: hoppin' bob
Dialogue: Gibson! Got yourself a visitor!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Mama?

Speaker: mama gibson
Dialogue: Rayford!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What are you doing here, mama?

Speaker: mama gibson
Dialogue: I heard some things so I went to see Spanky Johnson. He told me what happened and gave me some money to get down here. What happened to your face?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Don't worry about that. Hey, fellas, this here is my mama. These are some of my friends. That's Willie, there's Poker Face, Radio, Cookie, Goldmouth, Biscuit, Jangle Leg.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Mrs. Gibson. Shame on Rayford here for failing to mention that he had such a beautiful mama.

Speaker: mama gibson
Dialogue: Nice to meet you all.

Speaker: goldmouth
Dialogue: How was your train ride?

Speaker: mama gibson
Dialogue: Quite comfortable, thank you.

Speaker: cookie
Dialogue: Them cookies in there?

Speaker: mama gibson
Dialogue: Yes, oatmeal.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: 'Scuse me, you got any batteries on you?

Speaker: mama gibson
Dialogue: No. No I don't.

Speaker: biscuit
Dialogue: That's a lovely dress. Make it yourself?

Speaker: mama gibson
Dialogue: Yeah...

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: This is a big surprise, mama. I sure didn't expect to see you down here.

Speaker: mama gibson
Dialogue: Rayford, I wanted so much more for you than this.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Don't cry, mama. This place ain't so bad as it looks. Sure, we work hard, but there's plenty fresh air and sunshine... And you know something else, I've taken to going to church regular. They got services every Sunday right there in the mess hall.

Speaker: mama gibson
Dialogue: Don't you lie to me, Rayford.  Well, this is all I can give you. I wish it was more.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I can't take that, mama.

Speaker: mama gibson
Dialogue: Don't argue with me. You need it more than I do. I know how a little money can help in a place like this.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I can't believe this. I always said I'd never end up like this. I thought I'd make something of myself, do something with my life. You know, be successful. Have a big house, a family. Now I'm gonna end up just like daddy.

Speaker: mama gibson
Dialogue: Don't say that, Rayford. Don't ever say that. He gave up hope. That's where you gotta be different.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: They gave me life, mama.

Speaker: mama gibson
Dialogue: I gave you life. And they can't take it away from you. Remember that. You'll get outta here someday. I believe that. You gotta believe it, too.

Speaker: hoppin' bob
Dialogue: Time's up, Banks! We got a crowd gathering out here!

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Woman came all the way from New York, goddamnit! We'll come out when we're good and ready!

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Did you go see my cousin Maynard like I asked you in my letter?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Of course I did. He said he'd file an appeal right away. You didn't tell me he was so good looking.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Yeah, that side of the family has all the looks and none of the brains. I hope he don't mess things up.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: He seemed like a pretty good lawyer to me. His offices take up an entire floor of that big, new building on 125th Street, and he was using all these words I never heard before. He even offered me a job.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: A job, huh? Well, that's nice, real nice. You won't have to work long. I'll be back soon enough. After I start work at First Federal Bank of Manhattan, I'll be keeping you in style. Everything will get back to normal again. That's a promise.

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Listen, Claude, Maynard wanted to know if he should file the appeal on behalf of your friend, too.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Ray Gibson?  No, no. He's the reason I'm in here, Daisy. For all I know, he's got a record a mile long. I got a better shot of getting out of here on my own. You tell Maynard to think about me, concentrate on me. Understand?

Speaker: daisy
Dialogue: Sure, Claude, whatever you say.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: We lost yesterday on accounta the rain. That means we gotta make up for it today, so put your backs to it.

Speaker: hoppin' bob
Dialogue: You heard the boss! Let's move!

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Looks like a scorcher.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: I bet the son of a bitch goes over a hundred and ten.

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: I'll take that action.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Man down, boss!

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: You two, put him on the truck!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Cookie drew me a map to Greenville.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: So?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You know what I'm saying.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Yeah, I know what your saying. And I'm saying if you made it that far, they'd be watching every train that pulls out of that station.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: That's why we won't take the train. Cookie showed me where there's a farm house. They got a boat there.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: What do you know about boats? I bet you can't even swim.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What I know about boats is they take you to freedom. Come on, man. I think we can do this.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Why are you always talking about we? There is no we. There is a me, there is a you. But there is no we between us.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You want out of this place, don't you? Don't tell me you're starting to like it here.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: No, I don't like it here. Look around. There's nothing but ass. Male ass! Balls and ass! Believe you me, I'm getting out of here.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What does that mean?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Forget it.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I'm not gonna forget it. What does that mean? If you've got a plan, I think I have a right to know about it. I told you my plan.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Getting a map from a chubby chef named Cookie? Dragging our asses through the swamps in search of some worm-eaten boat? That ain't a plan, that's a vacation for two in the hole. When you've got a map to New York City, you get back to me.

Speaker: jangle leg
Dialogue: Sure was hot out there today.

Speaker: cookie
Dialogue: Still too hot to sleep.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: Every bone in my body feel like a big son-of-a-bitch dog got hold of it.

Speaker: goldmouth
Dialogue: I can't wait 'til Sunday.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: What's so great about Sunday? Monday's right after it.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: Hey, Ray, what's the name of that nightclub of yours?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You mean the Boom-Boom Room?

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: That's it. The Boom-Boom Room. Sure would like to see that place when you get it up and running.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You should have come by last night, Radio. You woulda had yourself some fun.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Last night? What are you talking about, Ray?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I'm talking about old Satchmo nearly blew the roof off the joint.

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Satchmo.

Speaker: goldmouth
Dialogue: You mean Louis Armstrong?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: He's a good friend of mine. Drops by the club whenever he's in town.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Hey, do we have to listen to this bullshit? I'm trying to get some sleep around here.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Yeah, things were hot last night, but you'll never guess who's playing tonight.

Speaker: biscuit
Dialogue: A tisket a tasket...

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: That's right, fellas. Catch any cab heading uptown. All the drivers know Ray's Boom-Boom Room.

Speaker: goldmouth
Dialogue: Where am I at, man?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: C'mon, Goldmouth, somebody's gotta watch the front door.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Hey, Ray, I could get used to this!

Speaker: cookie
Dialogue: Ray, my man, this steak is like butter!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Made just for you, Cookie.

Speaker: cookie
Dialogue: How about some steak sauce?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: No problem. Oh, boy!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: How about some Worchestershire sauce! And clean that damn table.

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: Hey, Ray, I know you got some gambling!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: C'mon, Poker Face, what's a club without some dice?

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: Lucky seven! My nigger! Let it ride!

Speaker: jangle leg
Dialogue: Sing, girlfriend!

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: Hey, Ray, looks like trouble!

Speaker: hoppin' bob
Dialogue: You don't shut up, you're gonna spend the rest of the night in the hole, Gibson! That goes for the rest of you girls, too. I don't want to hear another peep about no Boom-Boom fucking Room!

Speaker: cookie
Dialogue: Sorry, Cap'n.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: Pretty good story, Ray. Didn't much care for the ending though.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: Mail call!

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: Craddock!... Williams... Henshaw!... Banks!

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Here!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Maynard Banks, Esquire. Attorney at law.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Gimme that. That doesn't concern you.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I'm sure it don't.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: What's up, Ray?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Claude.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Sure is hot today. Think it'll rain later?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What do you want, Claude?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: What do I want? What makes you think I want something?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: My daddy always said when a man starts talking about the weather keep you hand on your wallet.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Your daddy must have been a helluva guy, a deep man, a wise man. Sure wish I could have met him --

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Cut the bullshit. What do you want, Claude?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: You still got that map?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Well, if you're still thinking about booking it, I want in. I think we can make it.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: We? Did I hear you say we? As I recall, you're the one who said there is no we. Guess we got some bad news in that letter, huh?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Look, my cousin Maynard is a lawyer. He filed an appeal on my behalf --

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: On your behalf. What happened to we?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: The appeal was denied. Then Daisy went and fell for Maynard. They're engaged to be married, can you believe that?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Well, let's just think about that for a moment. He's a successful lawyer up in New York City and you're down here with a bright future in the cotton picking business. Eeny, meeny, miney, Maynard.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Come on, man. Don't shut me out. I'm telling you, you and me, that map, we can go places.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You know what, Claude? This whole time we've been down here, you've done nothing but think about yourself, acting like this whole thing is my fault. That plan with your cousin, did that include me?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: At least you're honest for once. So now you want to be my friend? Well, let me tell you something, Claude-my- shit-don't-stink-Banks. You got a lot to learn about friendship.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Does that mean I'm in?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I don't think so, Claude. You'd just slow me down. We'd have to stop every five minutes so you could polish your silverware. There's no way around it, you're soft.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: What'd you say?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I said you're soft.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Don't call me that. You know I hate it when you call me that.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Damn, that felt good. I should have done that the first time I met you.

Speaker: hoppin' bob
Dialogue: Now you girls set aside your differences and get back to work or I'll see to it --

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: -- we'll spend a night in the hole. We heard this shit before.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: What the fuck are you laughing about?

Speaker: hoppin' bob
Dialogue: All in, boss!

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: Move it out.

Speaker: hoppin' bob
Dialogue: Movin' it out, boss.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: You did it, man! You got us out! Next stop, New York City!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: New York's a long way's off. Let's just keep moving, okay?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: I know these trees all look the same, but I'm getting an awful familiar vibration from this one right here. You sure you know where we're going?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Absolutely. The map is very clear.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Let me take a look at that map.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: You call this a map? What was Cookie smoking when he drew this?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Cookie didn't draw it. I did.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: You drew this?!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I knew you wouldn't come if I didn't have a map.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: That gripes my soul, man. We're out here in the middle of nowhere. There is shit nibbling at my balls! Don't tell me you don't know where we're going!

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Hey, wait up!

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Come on, Ray, time to go!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I'm stuck!

Speaker: mae rose
Dialogue: Look, daddy. They caught those two men who escaped last night.

Speaker: abernathy
Dialogue: They ain't men, Mae Rose. They're convicts. And nigger convicts to boot. Can you say nigger?

Speaker: mae rose
Dialogue: Nagger?

Speaker: abernathy
Dialogue: No, nigger.

Speaker: mae rose
Dialogue: Nigger.

Speaker: abernathy
Dialogue: That's my girl.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: Here they are, Superintendent. We tracked 'em all the way to the Tallahachie.

Speaker: abernathy
Dialogue: That's quite a ways. I'm glad you New York boys could see some of our lovely countryside while you're down here. What do you say, Mae Rose? How should we teach these two a lesson?

Speaker: mae rose
Dialogue: A night in the hole?

Speaker: abernathy
Dialogue: Better make it a week.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: See you in a week, boys.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Hey, Claude. I just want to say thanks for coming back for me.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Don't mention it.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Hell, you'd probably be half way to New York by now...

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: I'm serious, man. Don't mention it. Ever.

Speaker: cookie
Dialogue: I'll take Claude to die on Wednesday for fifty cents.

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: Wednesday for two bits. And don't forget you already owe me a steak.

Speaker: biscuit
Dialogue: I'll take Claude for Friday. That's my birthday.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: Weatherman says a heat wave's coming. I say neither one of 'em son of bitches gonna last past Thursday.

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: I told you before, I don't take pennies. Two cigarettes or one nickel minimum. What about you, Willie? Gonna get in on this action?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: I got a crispy new dollar bill says both of them gonna make it.

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: Now that's what I call a bet.

Speaker: goldmouth
Dialogue: It's a mighty long shot, Willie. Nobody ever made it a week in the hole.

Speaker: jangle leg
Dialogue: Not in August, anyway.

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: Who else has some guts around here?

Speaker: abernathy
Dialogue: I don't think these boys have learned their lesson. Let's give 'em another week for good measure.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: Sure you want to do that, sir?

Speaker: abernathy
Dialogue: Don't you ever question me, Sgt. Dillard. When I give an order, you jump to it, or I'll kick you and that first-cousin you call a wife outta that pretty little house so fast it'll make your pin-head spin. You got that?

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: Well, they made it a week. Looks like you win, Willie.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Let it ride.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Claude? You alright?!

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Can't take it no more, Ray! Die, motherfucker! Gotta get the fuck outta here!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Keep it together, Claude. You wake up the man, he'll shoot you for sure.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: He'd be doing me a favor. I'm getting outta here one way or the other! Goddamn rats and shit! Fuck!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: All right, man, just settle down. We'll get outta here, Claude. We'll get outta here real soon.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: How the fuck are we gonna do that, Ray?!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: We'll just get off at the next stop.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Say what?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: That's right, we'll get off at the next stop. The train's pulling into the station right now.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: The hell you talking about? What train?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: We're in the Bronx, my man. Hundred and Sixty First Street.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Hundred and Sixty First Street? That's Yankee Stadium.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Hell, yes, Yankee Stadium. Bombers are playing a double-header against the Red Sox.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Red Sox... Who's on the mound?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I don't know. Who do you want?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Allie Reynolds. He's my boy.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Sure, it says Allie Reynolds right here in the program. He's warming up right now. Man, we're so close to the field I need cleats. How'd you get such good seats?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: I know people.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: They must be the right people. Whoa, there goes the hot dog man. Let's get a couple. Damn, that smells good. Nothing like a ballpark hot dog, huh?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: You get ketchup?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Ketchup? Who eats ketchup on a hot dog? Mustard's what you want.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: I can't eat it with mustard.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Give me back that hot dog. I'll eat it myself.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: What am I gonna eat?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You can starve to death for all I care. Now shut up, the game's about to start.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Hey, man, is Babe Ruth in the lineup today?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Of course, he's in the lineup. There he goes right there. Hey, Babe...!

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: What's going on? Are they alive or dead?

Speaker: goldmouth
Dialogue: Don't look too good.

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: They're not moving.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Hey, Ray...

Speaker: abernathy
Dialogue: Sergeant Dillard, make sure these two are out in the fields first thing in the morning.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: Go on, get inside.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: ...Camp 8 is for incorrigibles, so whatever you've done to get here, believe me, we are not impressed. You new men are probably noticing that we have no fences here at Camp 8. We don't need no fences, we have the gun line. It runs from shack to shack clear around the yard --

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: What the hell you think you're doing?

Speaker: old guy
Dialogue: Excuse me, boss. That kid don't talk. Something wrong with his head, just can't get right, boss.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: Can't get right, huh? We'll see how long he last. Now, where was I?

Speaker: hoppin' bob
Dialogue: We don't need no fences at Camp 8, boss.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: That's right. We don't need no fences, we have the gun line. It runs from shack to shack clear around the yard. You are now inside the gun line...

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: If you step outside the gun line without my permission, you will be shot. If you trip and fall over the gun line, you will be shot. If you spit, if you pee, if you stick your ass out and take a dump over the gun line, you will be shot...

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: I try to teach 'em the finer points of the game, share my wisdom, but I don't know why I bother. They don't listen, they sure don't learn...

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What you're dealing with here is a complete lack of talent.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: I'm sick of watching Camp 12 win the championship. Every year they get to roast the victory pig and we get dick. This year I want that pig.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Alright, Radio, there you go. Who wants to hit next?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You want to hit?  Yo, Claude. Give Can't Get Right a shot.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Him?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Can't be worse than any of these other fools.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: All right, grab the bat. Let's see what you can do.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Jangle Leg's gonna throw the ball nice and easy. You just go ahead and take a swing.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Okay. Let's try that again. This time give it a little juice.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Told ya.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: I heard Camp 12 got themselves a son- of-a-bitch used to pitch for the Mud Hens.

Speaker: goldmouth
Dialogue: That boy got a year for jay-walking.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Judge must have money riding on the championship.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Don't matter who Camp 12 puts on the mound. All I know is when this season's over Camp 8's gonna have pork chops.

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: Looks like little Mae Rose has grown up.

Speaker: biscuit
Dialogue: And out.

Speaker: cookie
Dialogue: Mmm-mm, that girl's got gams.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: She's got it all. And it's firm and round and fully packed.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You shred it, wheat. That there is fresh water.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Be cool, man. You can look, just don't drool.

Speaker: abernathy
Dialogue: How was the honeymoon? Am I gonna be a grandaddy soon?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Afraid not. I'm shipping out this afternoon.

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: Think you can handle something that big, Cookie?

Speaker: cookie
Dialogue: I handled your mama, didn't I? Don't y'all worry. I got plans for that bad boy. Ain't none of him going to waste.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: Banks! Get over here!

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: This is Stan Blocker. Scout for the Nigger Leagues.

Speaker: blocker
Dialogue: Negro Leagues, actually. Pittsburgh Crawfords. Ever hear of us?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: We get the games on the radio sometimes.

Speaker: blocker
Dialogue: We played down in Jackson yesterday. Heard a rumor you've got a boy up here who can hit the ball a ton.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: You probably mean Can't Get Right. That's him over there.

Speaker: blocker
Dialogue: Can't Get Right? That's the kid's name? Can I talk to him?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: You can try, but you won't get too far. Why you interested?

Speaker: blocker
Dialogue: Crawford's are always looking for new talent.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Maybe you didn't notice, but this is a prison.

Speaker: blocker
Dialogue: There are ways around that. Right sergeant?

Speaker: blocker
Dialogue: Nice looking squad. See you after the game.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: You're my boy, just keep what little mind you have focused on the game. If you hit that ball the way I know you can, you might just be our ticket off this farm.

Speaker: blocker
Dialogue: Mark my words, within five years there's gonna be a colored man playing in the majors.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Come on, the world hasn't changed that much.

Speaker: blocker
Dialogue: Maybe not yet. But it will. And I'll be out of a job. Damn, that's some tasty hooch.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: It's amazing what Ray here can do with a couple of pounds of potato skins and some molasses.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: So, Blocker, what do you think of our boy?

Speaker: blocker
Dialogue: I think that boy could be the next Josh Gibson. I'm gonna talk to the front office about him, you can bet on that. Damn, it's getting late. We got a game in Memphis tomorrow.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: What about us? Don't forget to mention us.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: We're like his handlers. He can't function without us.

Speaker: blocker
Dialogue: I'll put in a good word for you. You've done a good job with that boy. Thanks for your hospitality.

Speaker: abernathy
Dialogue: Uh, doctor...

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: She'll be fine. She just had a bit of a shock.

Speaker: abernathy
Dialogue: Is Mae Rose okay?

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: She's doing just fine.

Speaker: abernathy
Dialogue: And the baby?

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: He's a big one.

Speaker: abernathy
Dialogue: It's a boy! Well, let's get a look at him.

Speaker: abernathy
Dialogue: Well, where is he? Where's my new grandson?

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: You really think they'll let him out of here just to play baseball?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Why not? Boy's got God-given talent.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: God may have given it, but Claude Banks spotted it and nurtured it.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Damn straight. I expect those Pittsburgh Crawdads to remember that.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Crawfords.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Whatever.

Speaker: cookie
Dialogue: Heads up, here comes trouble.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: Alright, listen up! I want every man lined up out here in the yard on the double! Let's move it!

Speaker: hoppin' bob
Dialogue: You heard what the man said! Move it!

Speaker: abernathy
Dialogue: I know it was somebody from this camp. I can feel it in my bones.

Speaker: abernathy
Dialogue: Do you know who the father of that little chocolated baby is?

Speaker: abernathy
Dialogue: Well, then, who is it?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: The baby's mine, boss.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: He's lying, boss. I'm the father of that baby.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Actually, it was me, boss. I know I may look old...

Speaker: biscuit
Dialogue: Any fool could see that baby's mine, boss.

Speaker: cookie
Dialogue: I beg to differ. That cute little rascal belongs to me...

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: I'm the father...

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: I'm the father, boss...

Speaker: goldmouth
Dialogue: I'm the father...

Speaker: jangle leg
Dialogue: I'm the father...

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: To Superintendent Abernathy. May he have many more grandchildren!

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: What I want to know is where? When? How?

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: Wasting your breath, Claude. He ain't the type to kiss and tell.

Speaker: clay's daughter
Dialogue: The magnolias are blooming early this year, daddy.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Don't take it so hard, Biscuit. She don't mean nothin' to him.

Speaker: biscuit
Dialogue: Hell with him. It ain't that.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: These are free papers.

Speaker: biscuit
Dialogue: What am I gonna do out there, Ray? I can't go home to my mama like this. I'll get the strap for sure.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Come on, Biscuit, this is good news. Your mama's gonna break down in tears when you show up on her doorstep.

Speaker: poker face
Dialogue: I'll give you three to one she gives him the strap.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: It's 1945. It's a different world now.

Speaker: biscuit
Dialogue: Not for me, it ain't.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Well you can't stay here, Biscuit. This ain't no life for a man. Any one of these fellas would give their right arm to be in your shoes. I sure know I would.

Speaker: biscuit
Dialogue: No life on the inside, no life on the outside...

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Hey, Biscuit...!

Speaker: trusty
Dialogue: Man over the line!

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: Goddamnit, Biscuit, get back here!

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: Hey, fellas, I got Chicago.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Hey, Can't Get Right, where you going? Why you dressed like that?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: It's a pardon from the governor.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Let me see that.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Where'd you get this?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Yo, Blocker, what's going on here?

Speaker: blocker
Dialogue: Kid's getting out. I got him a pardon.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Yeah, but what about me and Ray? I didn't see our names on that pardon. You said you were gonna put in a good word for us.

Speaker: blocker
Dialogue: I did, Claude. I mentioned you. I mentioned you both. But the fact is, pardons don't come cheap. The kid can hit. What can you do?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Let it go, Claude.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: I'm not gonna let it go. The man needs to explain himself. Makin' promises.

Speaker: blocker
Dialogue: Look, I am truly sorry about this. I'd like to help you...

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: But you can't.

Speaker: blocker
Dialogue: At least the kid's getting out. Isn't this what you wanted?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Yeah. Of course it is.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: You show them Crawfords how to play ball.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Make 'em throw strikes.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: It's alright. You're a free man now.

Speaker: blocker
Dialogue: Don't worry, we'll take good care of him.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: One of the new kids said they're farming those acres just north of the swamp. He said he saw a crop duster flying around the place.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: I'm not in the mood right now, Ray.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: He said they keep it parked out behind the barn. Can't be that hard to fly a plane. Lots of people do it.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: They're called pilots! I'm serious, Ray. I'm not in the mood for one of your stupid, fucked-up plans right now.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I don't see you coming up with any plans.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: My plan is on his way to Pittsburgh right now. That congenital idiot just got himself a pardon signed by the governor thanks to us, but we can't seem to do nothing for ourselves. Don't you feel a little disgusted right now?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Crop duster.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: I ain't getting in no airplane with you. I'm finally wrapping my mind around the concept. They threw us in this shithole for life. Don't you get it, Ray? We're gonna die here! Might as well head up to the cemetery, pick a plot and start digging.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: My daddy died in prison. He gave up hope and hung himself. What you're talking about is the same damn thing. That ain't how I'm going.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Maybe you're fooling yourself, Ray. Maybe you're just a chip off the old block.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Take that back or we ain't friends no more, Claude Banks.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Here's a news flash, Ray. We never were friends. We've just been stuck together for 12 years. It's been nothing but bad luck since the moment I ran into you. Every time I look at you I get sick to my stomach thinking about what my life could have been if I'd never bumped into Ray Gibson.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Better watch yourself Claude, before you say something you regret.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: The only thing I regret is the day I met you.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Well, if that's the way it is...

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: That's the way it is.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Then I have nothing left to say to you.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: You never said nothing of value anyway.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Alright Willie, I think I got everything. I'll talk to Dillard, see if I can get up to the infirmary and check up on you. Make sure they're changing your diapers regular.

Speaker: willie
Dialogue: They'll be sending you up there soon enough. And not just for a visit, neither.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I slipped in a couple of bottles of my latest batch. Help wash down all them pills they'll be giving you.

Speaker: yvette
Dialogue: Are you Claude Banks?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: yvette
Dialogue: My name's Yvette. Sylvia sent me. You look just like she said.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: She's alright, isn't she?

Speaker: yvette
Dialogue: Oh, she's fine. She's just not coming today.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: yvette
Dialogue: She got married last month.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Married?

Speaker: yvette
Dialogue: Real nice guy, too. Trumpet player. They moved down to New Orleans.

Speaker: yvette
Dialogue: She always said that if you were on the outside...

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: But I'm not on the outside. I'm in here.

Speaker: yvette
Dialogue: I know she's sorry she won't be seeing you anymore. Anyway, she wanted me to take care of you.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Take care of me?

Speaker: yvette
Dialogue: You know, go to the tonk or whatever.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: I'm too old for you. Besides, I'm not much in the mood.

Speaker: yvette
Dialogue: Want me to come back some other time?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Nice girl like you don't belong in a place like this. But if you talk to Sylvia, tell her old Claude said congratulations.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Whites-only pies...

Speaker: trusty
Dialogue: Man over the line!

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: Comfortable?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: As a pair of fur-lined bedroom slippers, boss.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: We'll see what those slippers feel like after, say, 24 hours. And if you step down off them bottles -- if one toe so much as touches the dirt -- one of these boys is gonna shoot you dead. Let's see. We need a special man for this job.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: How about it, Ray?

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: I'll make you trusty right now. If that pie-eatin' son of a bitch falls off those bottles and you have to shoot him, I'll see to it you get a pardon. Hell, I'll personally escort you out the gate.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You don't want to give me a gun, boss. I'm liable to use it on you.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: You're a sucker. I'd have taken that deal.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Excuse me? Are you talking to me?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: I'd have knocked you off those bottles, put a bullet in your ass and be half way to New York right now.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: After all these years of blissful silence, I almost forgot how annoying the sound of your voice can be.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: I hope you don't think I owe you anything. Because I don't owe you a damn thing.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I didn't do if for you, anyway. I just ain't no boot-licking trusty, that's all.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: I was sorry to hear about your mama passing.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: That was five years ago.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: I know, but since we're talking, I thought I'd mention it.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: We're not talking, you're talking, and doing too damn much of it, if you ask me.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: What?!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You sure looked funny running for those pies, bullets flying all around you.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Bullets weren't the problem. That pie was too hot. Burned my tongue.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: Fourteen acres today and only 12 hours of daylight! Eat up and move it out! Gibson! Banks! Get your sorry asses over here!

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: Every morning I wake up praying that Ray Gibson and Claude Banks have died in their sleep and every morning you disappoint me.

Speaker: dillard
Dialogue: I stand before you a defeated man. Try as I might, I can't seem to break you. I swear, if they dropped a nuclear bomb on this camp, you and the cockroaches would be the only things left. But starting today at least I won't have to endure your presence any longer. You've got fifteen minutes to clear out your footlockers. You're both being reassigned to the Superintendent's mansion. And I, for one, will not miss you.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I always wanted to do that.  There is so much love inside of this man.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Oh, yard boy, these pansies could use some attention over here. Perhaps some fertilizer would restore their exuberance.

Speaker: wilkins
Dialogue: Damn dentures slipping again. Everything falls apart when you grow old, eh, Claude? Time sure marches on.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Yes, boss.

Speaker: wilkins
Dialogue: You know, I'm fixing on retiring at the end of the summer, gonna try to enjoy what few years I have left. What do you think of this place? It's one of those new retirement communities down on the Gulf.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Ocean views, palm trees, two heated swimming pools and a golf course -- sounds a damn sight better than that infirmary across the way where I'm gonna end up.

Speaker: wilkins
Dialogue: I apologize, Claude. That was rude of me.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: That's alright, boss. Takes a lot more than a colorful brochure to hurt my feelings.

Speaker: wilkins
Dialogue: You been on the farm for quite a spell, haven't you?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Over forty years now. Me and Ray Gibson out there.

Speaker: wilkins
Dialogue: Forty years. That's a long time for any crime, even murder.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: It's a hell of a lot longer when you're innocent.

Speaker: wilkins
Dialogue: Half the men in this prison swear they're innocent. Don't you think that's kinda funny?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: You have to forgive me if I don't laugh.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You and Wilkins sure are getting chummy. You two planning on going steady, or something?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: He's just a lonely old man. He likes to talk.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Hey, I'm a lonely old man. I like to talk, too. So why don't we start by talking about what kind of a plan you're working on?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: I'm not working on a plan.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You can't fool me, Claude. I know you got something brewing.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Goodnight, Ray.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: What the hell are you doing?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Don't touch that car.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Wilkins' driver's got the flu, so he asked me to fill in for him.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You haven't driven in 40 years, you ain't even got a license. Man's taking his life in his hands, putting you behind the wheel! Where you taking him?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Greenville. We're picking up the new Superintendent at the bus station.

Speaker: wilkins
Dialogue: You know I trust you, Claude.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: wilkins
Dialogue: I'll be right back.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Damn, it was getting hot in there.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: What the hell are you doing in that trunk?!

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You didn't think I was gonna let you escape alone, did you?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: I ain't escaping! We're picking up the new super just like I told you.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Then you're lucky I came along. Doesn't take a visionary to spot a golden opportunity like this. Now help me out of this trunk.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: You ain't getting out of that trunk.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Come on, man, I'm starting to cramp up here.  We have the chance right here, right now, I say we go!

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Go where, Ray?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Back to New York for starters.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: And what will we do when we get there? I'm sixty-five years old, Ray. So are you. What are we gonna do out here? Get married, have kids, settle down? That boat sailed without us, man.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: This boat's gonna sail without you, too. I don't care if I last one day out here. At least it's one day of freedom. Now gimme those keys.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Forget about that. You run if you want to, but you're not taking this car.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Claude, man, I'm serious. Give me those keys.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: I ain't spending a month in the hole so you can take a joy ride.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Don't make me take them away from you.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Hey, there's Wilkins!

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Who's driving now, bitch?

Speaker: pike
Dialogue: There you go, boy.

Speaker: wilkins
Dialogue: Come on, Claude, time to go.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You sure it was him?

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: Some faces you just don't forget. Warren Pike's is one of 'em.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I don't like it, I don't like it one bit. We shoulda taken that car when we had the opportunity. We'd be half way to New York by now.

Speaker: claude
Dialogue: We'd be in the hole by now. Hey, man, you're peeing on my shoe.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I know. Simultaneously, they shake and zip. Claude bends down and picks up a bowl of gumbo, placing it on a tray next to an identical one.

Speaker: wilkins
Dialogue: Lemonade?

Speaker: pike
